EXIT   X

TERRORIST  FINANCING

Do you remember the scenario?

 

Click here for a reminder

 

 

What should you do next?

Scenario

You work as a customer service officer at Gondwana Finance, a company which provides loans and financing deals to individual and small business customers.

 

One day, a potential customer, Aiden, approaches you. He says that he wants to borrow a large amount of money from Gondwana Finance.

 

After you conduct a risk-profile assessment and carry out your KYC obligations, you notice some inconsistencies in the information Aiden has supplied to you. You are unable to verify Aiden's identity, or the nature of his business.

Check the DFAT blacklist and the Criminal Code Regulations and consider making a suspicious matter report

Contact AUSTRAC immediately

Approve the loan, as you have carried out your KYC obligations

 
 
 

That is correct!

 

Before accepting Aiden as a new customer, you need to check the DFAT blacklist and the Criminal Code Regulations, to ensure that he is not a person with whom dealing is prohibited by the government. You will be prosecuted for a terrorism-related offence if you deal with a blacklisted person or organisation, or if you are reckless as to whether money will be used to finance a terrorist act. Your organisation's AML Program should remind you to check the list and regulations.

 

You should make a suspicious matter report if you still suspect that Aiden isn't who says he is, or if there is information suggesting he is part of a blacklisted organisation.

That is incorrect

 

After carrying out your KYC obligations, you must check the DFAT blacklist and the Criminal Code Regulations, to ensure that Aiden is not a person with whom dealing is prohibited by the government. You will be prosecuted for a terrorism-related offence if you deal with a blacklisted person or organisation, or if you are reckless as to whether money will be used to finance a terrorist act. Your organisation's AML Program should remind you to check the list and regulations.

 

You should make a suspicious matter report if you still suspect that Aiden isn't who says he is, or if there is information suggesting he is part of a blacklisted organisation.

That is incorrect

 

After carrying out your KYC obligations, you must check the DFAT blacklist and the Criminal Code Regulations, to ensure that Aiden is not a person with whom dealing is prohibited by the government. You will be prosecuted for a terrorism-related offence if you deal with a blacklisted person or organisation, or if you are reckless as to whether money will be used to finance a terrorist act.

 

You should make a suspicious matter report if you still suspect that Aiden isn't who says he is, or if there is information suggesting he is part of a blacklisted organisation.
